citations.narrative:
The facility lost one duck due to predation within their primary enclosure. On November 24th, 2023, the facility noted the
duck was preyed upon by a raccoon that was able to compromise the aviary’s barrier and enter the primary the enclosure.
Ongoing threats due to predation are a concern for all avian species housed in their respective enclosures, as these
opportunities contribute to unnecessary stress, injuries, fear, and occurrences for trauma for all of the birds on-hand.
The facility must ensure that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds,
and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
Corrective actions were promptly taken by the facility following the event.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility’s program of veterinary care (PVC) has not been revised since the facility changed veterinarians. Upon the
previous vet’s retirement, the site started working with a new veterinarian in February of 2023, but the PVC has not been
updated to denote the new arrangements going forward.
The written program of veterinary care affirms both entities (facility and attending veterinarian) have a clear understanding
of their respective roles to provide appropriate care for the species housed. The facility should ensure that the written
program of veterinary care is available for review during all USDA inspections and accurately documents the
arrangements set forth at the facility.
Correct by February 9, 2024.

Two opened bags of dog treats were stored on top of a refrigerator in the room where the dog food is stored. Additionally,
two unopened bags of dog food were stored on the floor in the same room.
Failure to appropriately store supplied food items can compromise the nutritive value of the food items provided to the
animals, as well as enable easier access by bugs and pests to infiltrate the bags of food. All open supplies of food and
bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitted lids. Only food and bedding that is currently being used
may be kept in the animal areas. Supplies of food and bedding must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to
allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies.
Correct by January 25, 2024.

The facility’s current exercise plan has not been reviewed and approved by the new attending veterinarian. An approved
exercise plan ensures that adequate exercise opportunities are provided for the dog on-hand and is appropriate based on
its health status and physical needs. The facility shall maintain an appropriate exercise plan that’s approved by the
attending veterinarian and available during APHIS inspections for review.
Correct by February 9, 2024.

The facility has not updated the program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs to reflect the change in their attending
veterinarian. The new attending veterinarian began working with the facility in February 2023, but an updated PVC was
not available on today’s inspection.
The written program of veterinary care affirms both entities (facility and attending veterinarian) have a clear understanding
of their respective roles to provide appropriate care for the dog housed on-site. The facility should ensure that the written
program of veterinary care is available for review during all USDA inspections, including all required documented
arrangements outlined in this subchapter.
Correct by February 9, 2024.

The dates of administration for various treatments given to one dog housed at the facility were not recorded in full. The
adult male dog “Angus” received medicated ear drops in November 2023. Likewise, Angus received anti-inflammatory
medication in November 2023, and is currently being administered another course of anti-inflammatories. Although the
facility documented the initial management of these treatments, the remaining dates of administration were intermittently
recorded.
Adequate record keeping is necessary to ensure that the guidance of the attending veterinarian is being followed, and
helps the facility verify that medications were administered each day. The facility must keep and maintain the names of all
vaccines and treatments and the dates of administration given to dogs at the facility.
Correct by February 1, 2024.

On multiple occurrences, two otters escaped their outdoor enclosure while housed in their pond habitat. In October 2023,
the staff were unable to locate the otters for two consecutive days. On October 24th, 2023, the first otter was safely
caught, followed by the second otter a day later. The facility deduced both otters were able to escape through a hole
created in the fence line.
In November 2023 and December 2023, one otter escaped the pond exhibit again. The otter was seen on camera
climbing a tree to escape the enclosure in November and again in December by climbing the fence. On both instances,
the otter was safely captured and returned to its primary enclosure.
Animals escaping from primary enclosures are more vulnerable to harm and further injury when they are not safely
contained. They also pose a threat to other people and animals if they are not effectively held in their designated
enclosures as needed to complete routine responsibilities.
Housing facilities shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to contain the animals and protect them from
injury. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved.
The facility corrected after the occurrence of each incident.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
